I have received a Challeng from a person of Honour to meet her this Evening, Eight the time, a clear Stage, and no Quarter to be given on either side, and without Seconds Boy.

sp.speaker: Modish.
sp.p: At this rate you may, for all I know, be glad to turn Child again, and cry kings-truce for a breathing while; you take like Tinder and are transported with the Thoughts of your hot Ingagement like a raw Soldier, nothing but Fire and Fagot will content you; but after an Engagement or two, he fights with Moderation, keeps Rank and File and comes up with his Leader.

sp.speaker: Sparkish.
sp.p: I question not to come off with flying Colours: How malicious thou art, because thy cross Fate will not afford thee one happy Day in a year, thou wouldst have every body else under the like Circumstances: I hate such ill-humour'd snarling Companions; and so I leave you to fret in your Grease, 'till you return to a better Humour. Exit.

sp.speaker: Modish.
sp.p: I'le lay my life this Appointment is one of Lettice's contriving, to keep her Lady imploy'd while we are together in the Evening; how fond the Fool is of it!

q.l: Both Plants and Trees their certain Season know,
Rise with the Sun and wither when 'tis low;
Beasts their appointed time to seek their Prey,
They range all Night, and to their Dens at Day:
Yet Man the Lord of all, that's here below
Courts Care and Toyl, and will no time bestow
To ease his restless and disturbed Mind;
Courts what is bad, and leaves what's good behind.

div.trailer: The End of the Fourth ACT.

div.head: ACT V.
div.stage: Enter S. Peter Lovejoy, Friendly and Modish.

sp.speaker: Friendly.
sp.p: AS positive as you are S. Peter, I am not bound to pin my Faith upon any mans Sleeve in the World, neither will I be perswaded to act against my Reason, except you can bring better Arguments for what you have affirm'd, than I can against it; I won't be bubled out of that little Sense I have left me.

sp.speaker: S. Peter.
sp.p: What Argument would you have me undertake to gratifie your Curiosity? I'le use my weak Endeavours to give you satisfaction, if that will do.

sp.speaker: Friendly.
sp.p: Pray then make good, if you can, your Maxim, that you are always forcing upon People to make them believe there's no Whore after Marriage.

sp.speaker: Modish.
sp.p: If he makes that Argument good, it will go a great way in reconciling the World, and he will perform a friendly Office to the Publick.

sp.speaker: S. Peter.
sp.p: To the Point in hand then. First I would know if you take our Lawmakers to be wise and considerate men or no.

sp.speaker: Friendly.
sp.p: No doubt they were so; who denies that is to blame.

sp.speaker: Modish.
sp.p: Beyond all contradiction, there's no denying it.

sp.speaker: S. Peter.
sp.p: That granted you go a great way in confirming my Argument; for I find by my reading, that there can be no Bastard born in Wedlock, therefore no Whore after Marriage. What have ye to say against it Gentlemen?

sp.speaker: Modish.
sp.p: As I live the Knight speaks reason, deny it who can; I am convinc't.

sp.speaker: Friendly.
sp.p: On my word I cannot contradict what he saith, nor will I go about it.

sp.speaker: S. Peter.
sp.p: Nay 'tis but a Folly, having granted the Premises, to go about to deny the Conclusion. Let Reason rule you; and tho it be a vulgar Error which I have here confuted, sit down satisfied there are thousands mistaken besides your self, which I hope in a short time to convince and make sensible of their Errour.

sp.speaker: Modish.
sp.p: But in this case where the Husband is beyond the Seas your Argument will not hold good, the Law is expresly against you.

sp.speaker: S. Peter.
sp.p: Right, but there our Lawmakers were short-sighted; for is it reasonable because the Husband is beyond the Seas the Wife should lose her teeming? Besides she doth it out of meer necessity, and against that you know there is no Law.

sp.speaker: Friendly.
sp.p: As I live well answered; he hath both Sense and Reason on his side, and against that there is no disputing.

sp.speaker: S. Peter.
sp.p: This is nothing but what is common that I have made out to you; but I hear the Virtuoso's are about a Project, which if it take effect, will be worthy their Pains and Labour, and very beneficial to the World.

sp.speaker: Modish.
sp.p: What may it be S. Peter, if a man may inquire without offence, this use you speak of?

sp.speaker: S. Peter.
sp.p: I find you are out at Mystery; sure you converse with none but thick-scul'd Fellows you hear not of it; why they have undertaken, nay upon the matter brought it to perfection too, to make a Man a Woman.

sp.speaker: Friendly.
sp.p: An excellent Project this. But how is it so beneficial to the World as you talk of?

sp.speaker: S. Peter.
sp.p: There you are short again of your Comprehension: How many great Estates have been lost for want of an Heir?

sp.speaker: Modish.
sp.p: This doth not at all mend the matter, the making a Man a Woman; it had been something to have made a Woman a Man, that might have been of use where an Heir Male had been wanting.

sp.speaker: S. Peter.
sp.p: That's implied, if they compass the one the other comes of Course; for 'tis less trouble to make a Woman a Man, than 'tis to make a Man a Woman.

sp.speaker: Modish.
sp.p: I acquiesce Sir, and modestly submit to better Judgments.

sp.speaker: Friendly.
sp.p: But if this Argument prevails among us, where are all the Cuckolds and Witals the World hath so much talkt of? There are no such Creatures; 'tis strange we should be thus imposed upon, and swallow it for a Truth for divers Ages.

sp.speaker: S. Peter.
sp.p:
Why they are agreed, and gone a different Voyage,
the Witals to seek the Phoenix in Arabia, and the Cuckolds the Unicorn in the Isle of Pines.

sp.speaker: Friendly.
sp.p: Say you so Sir, then without doubt at their Return, they will make a saving Voyage of it; for a Phoenix and an Unicorn will be worth the seeing, being such Rarities as were never yet seen, tho much talk'd of; they must of necessity gain abundance of Wealth by them.

sp.speaker: S. Peter.
sp.p: No doubt of it, when these things come to pass they need not want Mony; for I look upon a Wital or a Cuckold, to be as strange, or a stranger sight than the Unicorn or Phoenix, and may as soon be found: But I have Affairs in hand which must not be neglected, and therefore must beg your Pardon for leaving you thus abruptly. Exit Sir Peter.

sp.speaker: Friendly.
sp.p: On my word, the Knight argues Reason, and by his Reading finds we are imposed upon, and frankly undeceives the ignorant, and deserves Commendations for his Care. I find we still may learn, tho we live never so long. Exit.

sp.speaker: Modish.
sp.p: This Fool takes all the other says for Oracles. How some are imposed upon, and yield to things incredible and non-sense; and are prevail'd upon to own Absurdities and Contradictions, both to Sense and Reason? By which we may see, there are Bigots in Opinions as well as in Religion; while sober Men abandon all such. Follies, and laugh at those that are deluded by them.

q.l: The Ignorant are thus abus'd and gall'd
By those, whose business is to Cheat the World.

div.stage: Enter Julia, and after her Lettice singing.

lg.l: Lettice. Since we poor slavish Women know,
Our men we cannot pick and chuse,
To him we love we say him no,
And both our time and labour lose.
By our put-off's and fond delays
A lovers Appetite we pall,
And if too long the Gallant stays,
His Stomach's gone for good and all.
Or our impatient Amorous Guest,
Vnknown to us away may steal,
And rather than stay for a Feast,
Take up with some course homely Meal:
When Opportunity is kind,
Let prudent Women be so too;
And if the Man be to her mind,
Be sure she do not let him go.
The Match soon made is happiest still,
For Love has only there to do;
Let no one marry 'gainst her Will,
But stand off when her Parents woo:
And to the Suiter be not Coy,
For she whom Joynture can obtain,
To let a Fop her Bed enjoy,
Is but a lawful Wench for Gain.

sp.speaker: Julia.
sp.p: Well thou art as mad a Lass as ever I met withall; fall Back, fall Edg thou art always merry.

sp.speaker: Lettice.
sp.p: Hang Sorrow, Care will kill a Catt, there's nothing gain'd by thinking, I say; it only brings People into Distempers: From a melancholy thinking Life I still pray to be delivered.

sp.speaker: Julia.
sp.p: And may'st thou have thy Wish I say: But how have you order'd Matters for our Meeting to night in private, as you promised?

sp.speaker: Lettice.
sp.p: Well enough I'le warrant you: I have provided my Lady a Companion, which if she parts with presently, I have lost my Aim and she her old Wont; when they are together we are secure for a short Space of time; I Song you the old Song to put you in mind of what you are going about, that you forget not to make use of your Time, for that's a precious Commodity as the World goes.

sp.speaker: Julia.
sp.p: I deserve, if I lose such an Opportunity as this, to be balk't ever after, and not so much as pitied by thee or any body else.

sp.speaker: Lettice.
sp.p: Come will you move toward your Chamber to recieve him when he comes? I'le take that care of you to bring you together, and leave you to agree the matter between your selves.

sp.speaker: Sparkish.
sp.p: Your Servant Lady, is my Lady Lovejoy within?

sp.speaker: Lettice.
sp.p: Yes Sir, that Door will bring you to the Room where she is waiting your Coming. Exit Sparkish.
So, there's one Couple provided for according to their wish; my next care is for the young Couple to see them fitted to their Minds.

sp.speaker: Modish.
sp.p: My Guide, my Convoy, now I see thee I am safe; I commit my self wholly to thy Care and Management.

sp.speaker: Lett.
sp.p: I should fit him finely now, if I should send him to yonder Couple in the Parlour; but that would so discourage him he would not look a Woman in the Face this Month, and by that time my Charge above stairs would pine her self to death. If you please to take the pains to walk up stairs, the first Room on the Right-Hand you will find the Lady you look for; pray be brief, and let's have none of your Canterbury Stories; make use of your Time.

sp.speaker: Modish.
sp.p: As near as I can I will observe your Directions; but still I am of that Philosophers mind, who blam'd Nature, and not without a Cause, who had given Man so long a Lesson and so short a time to learn it in. Exit.

sp.speaker: Lettice.
sp.p: How eagerly he pursues that which now he counts his Happiness! Like Children who are for the present fond of Trifles, but straight grow weary of them, and the next pleasing Object makes them quite forgotten; so some years hence discourse this eager Lover, he will tell you then that Marriage is a burden too hard for him to bear, and I who am now respected and rewarded for my Service, may then lie under the bitterest Curses that Malice can invent.

q.l: Before Injoyment Women Angels seemâ–ª
But afterwards they are of no Esteem:
Among our Gallants Mistresses are so Common,
They hate the name of Wife or Civil Woman. Ex.

sp.speaker: Friendly.
sp.p: Thou art always upon Extreams, sometimes nothing but a Woman can please thee, at another time, the very sight of a Woman puts thee into a disorder: Is there no meen between Loving and Loathing? But good Counsel is thrown away upon such obdurate men as thou art. Exit.

sp.speaker: Serious.
sp.p: Now I have the liberty to steer my Course which way I like best, it must be after the Female Sex still, tho I have suffered so deeply by them: I may talk of Religion, but that serves only to blind the World. Exit.

sp.speaker: Ralph.
sp.p: I have been in all the likeliest places hereabouts, to find this Master of mine, but can hear no News of him; he's got into some blind Corner or other with a Female Sinner: It is a strange thing nothing will Cure him of this Itch of Letchery; for he hath been used badly enough by that sort of Creatures, and to my knowledg is under Cure for his third Clap: But I must not give over hunting till I find him, and see him safe in his Lodging. Exit.

div.stage: Enter Sparkish, leading in Lady Lovejoy.

sp.speaker: Sparkish.
sp.p: Madam, the Obligations you have now laid on me, binds me for ever your devoted Servant; when shall I be thus blest again? Dear Madam, such Ravishing Delights as pass belief, dwell ever in your Eyes, and in your Face a Thousand Charms are moving; the least of which hath force enough to revive Nature setled on the Lees, and turn old Age to Youth.

sp.speaker: L. Lovejoy.
sp.p:
Sir, You are maker of your own good Fortune; if you style this your Happiness, 'tis in your power to give a daâ—e to
Love, and make it short or lasting, as you please; I am but like a Dial in Tempestuous Weather, of no use till you the Sun appear.

sp.speaker: Sparkish.
sp.p: If I may have my wish, we will lose no time, but Husband it still to promote our Happiness, that after Ages envying our Felicity, shall take their Measures from us, and Copy what we leave fairly Written.

sp.speaker: L. Lovejoy.
sp.p: 'Tis still the fate of Lovers to be at first extreamly fond and Court-like, till time that alters all things, makes us Common and Cheap to one another; if not, Age won't be hid; and then what seem'd so fair and lovely to us, is defaced and blottedâ–ª like Garments out of Fashion, not regarded; so Love, as Age grows on, declines, and nauseates what before it most longed after.

sp.speaker: Sparkish.
sp.p: With sickly Appetites all nourishment is loathsome, but you have Charms that still create more liking, and add a Lustre to your heavenly Form, which Captivates at sight.

sp.speaker: Lettice.
sp.p: Madam, I hear my Master in the Street, he is coming home; I thought it part of my Duty to give your Ladyship notice.

sp.speaker: L. Lovejoy.
sp.p: 'Tis well done, go to Bed, I'le let your Master inâ–ª Your absence will now be necessary.

sp.speaker: Sparkish.
sp.p: Madam, Your Servant.

sp.speaker: L. Lovejoy.
sp.p: That Door will lead you the Back-way out; your Servant Sir, good Night. Ex. Sparkish.
By this means I may make a Discovery, and see what humour my Knight is in when he is Top and Top-Gallant; for being faulty my self, makes me have a mighty suspicion of other People.

div.stage: Knocking without, L. Lovejoy blows out the Candle, then opens the door.

sp.speaker: Sir. Peter.
sp.p: Well Lettice, Is thy Mrs. safe?

sp.speaker: L. Lovejoy.
sp.p: Whist, Whist.

sp.speaker: Sir Peter.
sp.p: Nay, I can be as silent as any body if that will do; march on tho it be dark, I shall make some shift or other to follow my Leader.

div.stage: Enter Modish leading in Julia, Lettice following them.

sp.speaker: Modish.
sp.p: Transporting Joys are always short and fleeting, not permanent and durable; the satisfaction scarce balances the loss of parting with them; your beauteous form hath made such deep Impression in me, that wanting you I want my better part, and can no more reach Happiness without you, than Fruit in Autumn ripens without Sun-shine.

sp.speaker: Julia.
sp.p: This is no time for long Discourses Sir, the Night's far spent, and I am indisposed, and much disordered.

sp.speaker: Lettice.
sp.p: Come Sir, Face to the Right, and follow your Leader: I'le conduct you out, 'tis time to part.

sp.speaker: Modish.
sp.p: And must we part? Farewel till next we meet, thou Beauteous Soul: Eternal Love wait and attend upon thee. Exit.

sp.speaker: Julia.
sp.p: The thoughts of future happiness still make us undergo the greatest Slavery and Servitude without Repining; but slighted once, nothing exceeds the malice of a Woman.

q.l: We Love beyond belief, but if men prove
Once false, our hatred far exceeds our Love.

sp.speaker: Lettice.
sp.p: So, with much ado they are separated; had I let them alone this month together, the last Tune would have been Loath to depart: The truth of it is, I should be of the same mind, were the Case my own, as now 'tis theirs.

q.l: Love knows no Bounds, and moves no common Way,
An Age with Lovers seems but a short day. Exit.

sp.speaker: Flavia.
sp.p: When every bodies turn is serv'd, it may be I may be remembred, for 'twould be hard to lye alone all my life-time; but afterwards to lead Apes, is a thing I abhor the thoughts of.

div.stage: Enter Lady Lovejoy, and Sir Peter following her.

sp.speaker: L. Lovejoy.
sp.p: Urge me no more, you know I am in my Nature reconcilable, and therefore you use me as you do.

sp.speaker: Sir Peter.
sp.p: Thou art as Waspish this Morning, as the Barber that kill'd his Horse, because he would not stand to be trim'd.

sp.speaker: Lady Lovejoy.
sp.p: You are as void of Sense as the Woman, that because her Gallant turn'd her off, discover'd the Intriegue to her Husband, and made a Westminster business of it.

sp.speaker: Sir Peter.
sp.p: I think Edmonton Air hath made thee sharp-witted; you are so quick at Repartee, there's no speaking to you.

sp.speaker: L. Lovejoy.
sp.p: There is no Air will alter you from what you are: A dull Drone, that cannot make a Warrant without the Statute-Book, nor a Mittimus without the help of your Clark, forsooth.

sp.speaker: S. Peter.
sp.p: Prithee be not so angry, we have all our failings; thou know'st we must bear with small faults.

sp.speaker: L. Lovejoy.
sp.p: Here's another that creates me trouble hourly, but I'le quit my hands of her: Lettice, I would have you provide your self of a place, for I find you are not for my turn, therefore pray pack up, and be moving: There's what is due to you.

sp.speaker: Lettice.
sp.p: Short warning, I would gladly know the Cause.

sp.speaker: L. Lovejoy.
sp.p: 'Tis enough I will have it so.

sp.speaker: S. Peter.
sp.p: She hath been a good Servant to thee; don't turn her away for a small fault.

sp.speaker: L. Lovejoy.
sp.p: You may do what you please with your Men, pray let me alone with my Maids.

sp.speaker: Lettice.
sp.p: Your Servant Madam, I can dispose of my self without giving you a further trouble.

sp.speaker: L. Lovejoy.
sp.p: Stay, and take that along with you: gives her mony. I earn'd that last Night for you; you had had it then, 'twas designed for you, but being gone to Bed you mist of it; and I should be as unjust as you, should I defraud you.

sp.speaker: S. Peter.
sp.p: Sits the Wind in that Door? then 'tis time for me to be moving, for fear of an after-Reckoning; in a little time her heat will be over. Exit Sir Peter.

sp.speaker: L. Lovejoy.
sp.p:
You see by this, and find by dayly experience, that your sly pretending Coxcomb, who one would think, had neither Life nor Soul in him, will be as sweet on a Whore in a Corner, as the daring Hector, who makes it his business to Debauch himself and others; yet I am still of the Opinion, your half-witted Men make the best Husbands, because they are fittest to be imposed
upon, and may be wrought into what Form we best like of.

q.l: We Marry that our Loves may setled be,
Yet nothing pleases like Variety.

sp.speaker: Lettice.
sp.p: Ladies, You see at last I am deserted by my Lady, who have made it my whole employment to serve you to the utmost of my power, but am now out of a Capacity to serve you further.

sp.speaker: Julia.
sp.p: There can be nothing laid to thy Charge by us; we must own thou hast been diligent in thy Office: But you must finish the work you have begun, or we are in a worse Condition than ever.

sp.speaker: Flavia.
sp.p: If she leaves us now in this perplexing doubt, 'tis Inhumanity beyond Example.

sp.speaker: Lettice.
sp.p: Ladies I would not have you despair, but be assisting in contriving your own good Fortune; there shall be nothing wanting in me to forward it, if it be in my power.

sp.speaker: Julia.
sp.p: Set us but in the way; then, if we follow not thy Directions the fault lies at our Door, not yours.

sp.speaker: Flavia.
sp.p: Do but tell us what we shall do to attain what you have so successfully hitherto carried on, and leave us to perform it.

sp.speaker: Lettice.
sp.p: If I must still be concern'd in your Affair I'le try my Skill; I think this Plot may take: 'Tis Madam Julia that they all adore, but can but one possess her; therefore to carry on our Design she must promise them all fair to draw them into the snare of Matrimony, upon this condition, that they shall be content to be married after the Masquerading way, in a Disguise; for by that means we may all be provided for to our wish; for Mr. Sparkish desires this day to court her for his Wife; the other two you know have long been Suitors: This will be no great Task to undergo; and this performed we gain what we desire.

sp.speaker: Julia.
sp.p: True Lettice, still thy Plots are laid above the reach of Fate to frustrate or prevent.

sp.speaker: Lettice.
sp.p: Now I'le leave you and possess Modish with our Stratagem, and leave the rest to you. Exit.

sp.speaker: Julia.
sp.p: Now Sister what remains, but that we carry on this Plot with Secrecy so happily begun?

sp.speaker: Flavia.
sp.p: It must of force be prosperous; you shall have Modish: let Sparkish be my Prize, and leave the old dissembling Letcher Serious for Lettice to convert.

sp.speaker: Julia.
sp.l: Agreed, and all are satisfied.
Where differing Humours meet there's always Strife;
But all Contentment in a married Life. Exeunt Ambo.

sp.speaker: Sparkish.
sp.p: As I have used your Brothers House, I still observed that Sweentness in your Carriage and such transcendent Beauty in your Face as cannot be resisted; what I have said of you, is notâ–ª strange but common, being the Talk and wish of all Beholders.

sp.speaker: Julia.
sp.p: In Rallery and Jest, not Earnest sure.

sp.speaker: Sparkish.
sp.p: Such Divine Forms as yours, are rather to be worship'd and ador'd than made our Mirth and Pastime.

sp.speaker: Julia.
sp.p: Now you betray the worst of Natures, Flattery, and think I take what you speak in Rallery, for real Truth.

sp.speaker: Sparkish.
sp.p: You wrong me much, my Heart and Tongue agree: I heard by chance that Modish long had wooed you, which brought me now to know if my small service and the Love I owe you may be accepted with you.

sp.speaker: Julia.
sp.p: Would you be so unkind to wrong your Friend and prove his Rival in the Choice he hath made?

sp.speaker: Sparkish.
sp.p: Would I not? What is't I would not do to gain your Favour? Make me a promise that I shall enjoy you, impose what 'ere you will I'le undergo it with as much Willingness as I would eat or drink to strengthen and support decaying Nature.

sp.speaker: Julia.
sp.p: In that Sir I'le never promise any man, but am resolved who 'ere I marry it shall be in a Disguise; and that you may know I have no Aversion for your Person I'le make you of my Council: To Morrow I design to alter my Condition, if you dare venture to take your Lot or Chance; I am ti'd to make no further Discovery, you may. I will provide a Non-con shall joyn us, for here will be two more of the same Humour to marry in Disguises: Now if you dare to venture, so; if not, farewel. Exit.

sp.speaker: Sparkish.
sp.p: Come what may come I'le venture, for I am acquainted with her Sister and Lettice too, by which means I may inform my self as to her Garb and Dress that I mistake not this great Concern and hug a Cloud for Juno.

sp.speaker: Sparkish.
sp.p: I was just coming to find you out about a matter that concerns me much, my Happiness depends upon it.

sp.speaker: Lettice.
sp.p: If I can serve you you know you may command me to my power.

sp.speaker: Sparkish.
sp.p: Know then to Morrow is the time appointed: I am to take my Choice unsight unseen, as the saying is: Now if by any means you can inform me which of the three is Julia, for so many there is to be provided for, you'll eternally oblige me.

sp.speaker: Lettice.
sp.p: It happens so that I am of the Council, and therefore can inform you; but am obliged to Secrecy, and 'tis not generous to betray my Trust, nor can I.

sp.speaker: Sparkish.
sp.p: Here's Gold for thy Reward; give me some private Mark to know her by is all I ask.

sp.speaker: Lettice.
sp.p: If I may counsel you, take the middle-most as they stand together; you need no more direction.

sp.speaker: Sparkish.
sp.p: A word's enough to the wise: What Luck had I to think of this kind Creature to direct me! Exit.

sp.speaker: Lettice.
sp.p: Now will he be cousen'd as the Dog who thought he had been going to Breakfast, and was going to be hang'd. But 'tis no matter, what she design'd for him will be good enough and too good without he were better.

q.l: Who knows, when married, but his roveing Mind
May keep one center and to one prove kind. Exit.

sp.speaker: Friendly.
sp.p:
A pretty Frolick this, to be married Incognito, as they call't; but were I concer'd they should look the Bridegroom where they could find him for me; this is like buying a Pig in a Poke, as the old saying is. Well I would have you as my Friend to look before
you leap; they will put some Trick upon you, you had best take heed.

sp.speaker: Serious.
sp.p: No, no, I am safe enough for that; I have a private Mark to know her by; besides I have undergon so much to gain her Favour as might fill a small Romance; and do you think she will after all deceive me? You wrong her much to start this Question Sir, and me in harbouring such hard Thoughts of her, and were you not my Friend, I should as old as I am, demand satisfaction of you for the Affront offer'd.

sp.speaker: Friendly.
sp.p: I only put the Worst, the Best will help it self; and if for this you are angry you may turn the Buckel of your Girdle behind you, for any thing I care.

sp.speaker: S. Peter.
sp.p: What angry one with another? Let's know the Cause: I'le make you Friends again or it shall cost me all the Mony in my Pocket.

sp.speaker: Friendly.
sp.p: The matter is not worth the speaking of, Mr. Serious can inform you if he pleases the Reason of our Difference.

sp.speaker: Mr. Serious.
sp.p: I'le as soon be hang'd, cant a Man speak a hasty Word but it must presently be brought upon the Stage? I have no Quarrel with any man living that I know of, so be satisfied.

sp.speaker: S. Peter.
sp.p: I am very well satisfied there is no difference between you; for my part you are both my Friends and therefore was concern'd.

sp.speaker: Friendly.
sp.p: 'Twas kindly offer'd. Where do you dine to day, At home or abroad?

sp.speaker: S. Peter.
sp.p: At Tom's, where Modish gives a Venison Pasty, where I am sure your Company will be as acceptable as any that's there.

sp.speaker: Friendly.
sp.p: I guess no less and shall be glad to wait on you. What say you Mr. Serious?

sp.speaker: Serious.
sp.p: I think to meet you there, but have some Business of importance must be dispatch'd first, then I am for you Gentlemen.

sp.speaker: S. Peter.
sp.p: Well, we'll expect you Sir. Come Uncle we'll in and drink our Mornings-draught, and then set forwards. Ex. omnes.

div.stage: Enter Julia, Flavia and Lettice disguis'd on one side. Modish, Sparkish and Serious on the other side.

sp.speaker: Modish.
sp.p: This World's a Lottery; where still the least deserving are most prosperous, and the best natur'd, meet the most Misfortunes. Besides, we are imposed upon, for to one Prize you will find a thousand Blanks; yet like frank Gamesters still we will be pushing and urge Ill Fortune to our overthrow, still in pursuit of that which must torments us, and part with all our Faculties at once to follow what another shall think equal.

sp.speaker: Sparkish.
sp.p: By the World thou art in the right, for in this case there can but one possess the Lovely Julia, the other two must take what's left; you are contented I first make my Choice.

sp.speaker: Serious, Modish.
sp.p: We are.

sp.speaker: Sparkish.
sp.p: Then here I fix, and laugh to see you Two deceived and cheated, while I possess the beauteous Julia, in whose Arms I'le sport my self and dare Ill Fortune to disturb my Peace.

sp.speaker: Serious.
sp.p: I smile to see how confident the Fool is, but I am on sure ground, and here I make my Choice, and think my self as happy as Conquering Soldiers laden with their Spoils, or Shipwreck't Men just landed.

sp.speaker: Modish.
sp.p: Then what remains, but that I take this Lady, and fancy her to be the Heavenly Julia? Now to the Priest, who stays in the Dining-Room, where joyned, we then shall know our certain Dooms, who we are tied to lead our Lives withall. Exeunt.

div.stage: Enter Sir Peter Lovejoy, Lady Lovejoy and Friendly.

sp.speaker: S. Peter.
sp.p: A Masquerading say you? I thought that had been out of Fashion.

sp.speaker: Friendly.
sp.p: In short Sir, they are both gone to be married, and Lettice with them; she's to have a Husband too among them.

sp.speaker: L. Lovejoy.
sp.p: Sir Peter, you have manag'd your matter finely, to let them be disposed of unknown to you.

sp.speaker: S. Peter.
sp.p: Tricks of youth, tricks of youth: Girls will have their Frolicks.

div.stage: Enter Serious leading Lettice, Sparkish leading Flavia, Modish leading in Julia.

sp.speaker: Serious.
sp.p: I beg your pardon Sir Peter, for marrying your Sister without your Consent.

sp.speaker: Sir Peter.
sp.p: What Sister?

sp.speaker: Serious.
sp.p: Julia. Lettice pulls off her Mask.

sp.speaker: Lettice.
sp.p: Lettice if you please, for so I think they call me.

sp.speaker: Serious.
sp.p: What, Cheated! Put upon!

sp.speaker: Sparkish.
sp.p: Then I must beg your excuse, for making bold without your leave, with your Beauteous Sister Madam Julia.

sp.speaker: Sir Peter.
sp.p: Hey day, how many Julia's shall we have? Sure they drop out of the Clouds there is so many of them.

sp.speaker: Flavia.
sp.p: Prepare you to see a Face, though not so Beauteous, yet as true as Julia's. pulls off her Mask

sp.speaker: Sparkish.
sp.p: Tricks as I live! By the World, as Modish says, I think the World is a Lottery; but we are got among Prizes, I see no Blanks.

sp.speaker: Modish.
sp.p: Then sure the faithful Julia is my Wife; for yet she is conceal'd: Come push aside this Cloud, and shew thy Beauty.

sp.speaker: Julia
sp.p: Then be it as you wish, you have your Julia, and I the Man I love above the World.

sp.speaker: Modish.
sp.p: Come Gentlemen, let discontent be banished from all Faces, and only Joy appear: You know the old Proverb is, Marriage and Hanging goes by destiny. Come, the Venison Pasty is ready by this time: Let's Laugh it out, and make a merry day on't.

sp.speaker: Sir Peter.
sp.p: First satisfie this good Company how you like your Mornings Work, and then we are for you.

sp.speaker: Sparkish.
sp.p: Agreed: Come Mr. Serious, you were married first, and are the most likeliest to find fault, therefore pray lead the way.

sp.speaker: Serious
sp.l: By me you may perceive as Age grows on,
How we poor Animals are put upon:
Of a bad Chance, 'tis well it proves no worse,
I doubt not but she will make a careful Nurse.

sp.speaker: Sparkish
sp.l: Tho Chous'd by Madam Julia, yet I find
Great satisfaction in my roving Mind:
This Flavia proves as Chaste as Babes new born,
And sweet as Rose-buds in a Summer Morn.

sp.speaker: Modish
sp.l: My Joy's too great in words to be exprest.
In faithful Julia I am double blest:
Fortune hath made amends for all her Spite;
Thus after Darkness we rejoyce at Light.

sp.speaker: Sir Peter
sp.l: Since all seem satisfied, why should not we
With Mirth and Joy conclude this Comedy;
Forget what's past, and let this happy Night
Conclude all Quarrel, and set all things Right.

sp.speaker: Friendly
sp.l: Could we but hope that you were pleas'd, we then
Should rest satisfied, like happy Men;
Who what this World affords, they do possess;
But your dislike is our unhappiness.

div.head: The EPILOGUE.
div.l: CVSTOM prevails, and you expect we know
To hear an Epilogue before you go.
Our Poet finds your Appetites are nice,
And dares not rule, but gives you this Advice;
Be govern'd by the Learned in the Laws,
Who before Judgment always trie the Cause,
And afterward, if for the first Offence,
In gentle and kind Terms express their Sense
In hopes of the Offenders Reformationâ–ª
At least they will allow him Transportation,
Such is the Goodness of our English Nation.
Then why should you, who here as Judges sit;
Count all but Dross that is not like your Wit?
Wit may be Wit, tho not so finely drest,
As Sense without an Oath may be exprest.
Pray tell me Gallants, is the Face the worse
Because the Garment's Country like and Course?
You are for Beauties, as you are for Wits,
Nothing but what's Extream your Fancy fits.
He that writ best never could please you long,
Sometimes your Humourâ–ª lies towards a Song;
But that must be well worded, and refin'd,
Thus various are the Motions of your Mind,
As Fishmongers say by their Wares, the Play
And Poet too are fresh and new as they.
Novelties use to please you, but of late
Nothing will do, such is your cruel Fate:
We court your Love, but still we meet our Hate.
If you resolve still to be so severe
Thus few will try their Wits to treat you here,
But spend what's left, where Men more kind will prove
At least they will return us Love for Love.
They're void of Care and Strife wee'l spend our Days
In Love and Friendship, and ne're think of Plays.
'Tis the first Fault, and therefore Sirs be kind,
And let the Play a kind Reception find.
